comments.commentBody: "A person's identity is a cultural construct and has nothing to do with blood line/genetic/race" - Try telling that to someone with Tay-Sachs or Sickle cell anemia or any number of different cancers. Go on, try it.

Tay-Sachs disease occurs in Ashkenazi Jews, Cajuns in Louisiana and some French Canadians. I am sure these groups have different self-identities though they share the same mutated genes that causes Tay-Sachs.

People from all kinds of backgrounds and genes identify themselves as Americans, which is a cultural construct and not by blood-lines.

A Jew whose family has lived in Britain for generations most likely would identify himself as a Briton first, which, again, is a cultural construct and not genetically determined.

Yes, Sickle Cell anemia occurs in people of African descent, but people of African descent live all over the world. They would identify themselves as South Africans, Ghanese, Sudanese, etc., etc., and yes, Americans. Again, people with Sickle Cell anemia may share the same genes, but, due to cultural construct, they identify themselves differently.

So I tried.

I would bet there are Danish who lives in Denmark but are of Taiwanese descent. I've met a couple of them in a Copenhagen restaurant. They did identify themselves as Danish. I am sure their second or third or fourth generation descendant would self-identify themselves as Danish, even if they do not have a drop of Danish blood in their genes.
"Could I claim to be Native American and give myself a name, parade around talking about my ancestors and the hardships they suffered, etc. just because it's what I THINK I am?" Of course you can, if you really feel that you are a Native American. Tell me why not?

By the way, the meaning of "Han" has its mysterious origins. It is a cultural construct. Its meaning changes with changes of the social and political circumstances. It's the same with the concept of "Zhong-Hua-Min-Zu" -- there was no such nationality until the early 1900's when Liang Qi-Cao proposed the term, trying to raise Chinese nationalism. Again, it is a cultural/political construct.

A person's identity is a cultural construct and has nothing to do with blood line/genetic/race. Self-identity is more of a software thing (what you think you are) than a hardware appearance (what you look like). Through the long history of human race, identity politics have been used to play a major role in human conflicts - from racism to genocide. Remember the Balkan War? Same race with different identities massacre each other. Russia is using its "Russian" identity to expand its influence and grab territories (to restore "Russian World"). China claims that Taiwanese belong to Han blood-line and therefore Taiwan is part of China, even though more than 85% of Taiwanese people carry aborigines genes. More importantly is that a majority of Taiwanese considered (software) themselves Taiwanese and not Chinese.
It is entirely appropriate for Rachel Dolezal to identify herself as black or even "African-American"; whether she looks black or not, or if she has African blood line are inconsequential.

Most of what you have posted is sensible ... however, I can't get my head around how on earth can you say the Kurds loyalties lie with turkey? Don't you realize the turks conducted an operation of cultural cleansing and genocide against the Kurds for years? turkish antipathy toward the kurds continues to this day, as the turks will not open their border with syria, in order to allow Kurdish fighters from turkey to cross over to support Kurds menaced by isis in syria.

And if you think turkey is a secular democracy, either you are not keeping up with events over there, or you don't know what secular democracy is.

The turks are an occupying force who must leave the Kurdish areas and allow the Kurds living there to decide their own fate.

In the shifting sands of mid-east loyalties, where even a staunch ally like Israel can be governed by someone no longer interested in peace, the Kurds have been on our side from the first Gulf War forward. Their loyalties lie more with Turkey than with Iraq but Turkey is a model (so far) of a secular democracy in a Muslim country. It is one of the few sects in the area who don't turn on us even though our history with them has been heavily one sided. Iraq is gone. Give the Kurds the north, call it Kurdistan, and they will fight to the death. It will also establish the first border in the new middle east. The Suunis and Shias can fight, or negotiate, over the rest of the country. It took a brutal dictator to keep these long simmering hatreds suppressed but now that we let that genie out of the bottle, we should let them work it out. Iraq was a fiction to begin with. I don't want anymore Americans dying for a fiction.

The Kurds were our best military allies during the 13 months of Operation Iraqi Freedom duty that I pulled in 2005-2006. Vice President Joe Biden once said that the best solution for the Iraq problem was to divide the country into 3 separate states. Kurdish, Sunni and Shia. VP Biden had it right then and even though out of loyalty to the Commander In Chief he won't say it again I will echo his past advise. Iraq was created by the British following WW1. It has been an oft times bloody mess ever since. Let the Kurds secede from Iraq. Then let Sunni tribes loyal to the U.S. have the middle section. As far as the Persh Merga payroll, well maybe U.S or other allied personnel should take over finance and logistics until the Kurds can do those essential military support tasks on their own.

The Kurds are the only people in the region that have consistently shown they can build governments and institutions that will actually help their people.  They have fought consistently and with bravery.  They treat women with respect and deserve their own state.  If anything is a stabilizing force in the Middle East, it's the Kurds.  Instead, we talk about bolstering the useless government of al Maleki, and continue to 'train' forces that consistently run away, when confronted by ISIS.  Since we throw arms into the ME and hope they get to the right hands, why not throw some of them to the pesh merga who seem to be the only ones willing to stand up and fight.
In addition to kurds, the public mobilization milita is gaining momentum and secured bright success.

They are the only people in Iraq whom we can trust and rely upon.
Saladdin was Kurdish. They are brave, tough, and don't treat their women like chattel. I say let them take as much land as they can.
